p:
Humans contribute to the larval sites directly or indirectly through agriculture, polyculture, and urbanization ( 10, 11, 33), therefore increasing the environmental carrying capacity for larval development which is captured in Model B. In general, the higher the human population in a given area (ρ), the more the larval sites ( d). The lower the socio-economic level, the more the water storage and waste containers that allow Aedes mosquito to develop. We assume that the number of larval sites d is proportional to the human population and inversely proportional to the economic level, which we approximate by the square root of the ratio of GDP/capita ( g) to the world average value ( g
a )—see Equation (5) in Supplementary Material ( Table S1B) for details. Human contribution to blood meals is accounted as an extra factor h (human blood-meal factor), which describes the possible reduction in oviposition rate outside laboratory (ideal) conditions.
